questions.text:
1. Match the following:

1. Organic irritants  a. Opiod
2. Metallic irritants b. Croton
3. Deliriant c. Cocaine
4. Depressant d. Lead
questions.solution:
The correctly matched class of poisons with their examples are: 

Type of Poison Example
1. Organic irritants  b. Croton
2. Metallic irritants d. Lead
3. Deliriant c. Cocaine
4. Depressant a. Opiod


Poisons may be classified according to the chief symptoms that they produce:

* Organic irritants include (a) Vegetable- Abrus precatorius, castor, croton, calotropis, aloes and (b) Animal- Snake and insect venom, cantharides, ptomaine

* Metallic irritants include arsenic, antimony, copper, lead, mercury, silver, and zinc

* Delirants include datura, belladonna, hyoscyamus, cannabis, and cocaine

* CNS depressants include alcohols, general anaesthetics, opioid analgesics, hypnotics, and sedatives.

The seeds of croton (jamalgota, jaipala, naepala) contain crotin, a toxalbumen (image below). They can produce hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, vomiting, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse and death. When applied to the skin, the oil produces burning, redness and vesication.



Lead is a metallic poison which interacts with sulphydryl groups and interferes with the action of enzymes necessary for heme synthesis, and for haemoglobin and cytochrome production. It interferes with mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation, ATPases, calcium-dependent messengers and enhances oxidation and cell apoptosis. It also causes haemolysis.

Cocaine is obtained from the leaves of Erythroxylum coca (image below). It is a powerful stimulant of CNS for a short time, followed by depression. Similar but less marked effect is seen on the spinal cord. It is an excitant and stimulator of autonomic nervous system. It has sympathomimetic properties.



Opioids exert their effects because of their chemical similarity to natural substances called endorphins. The opiate drugs activate receptor sites normally occupied by the natural opiates or endorphins. It depresses all centres except oculomotor, vomiting and sweating. It is a peripherally acting analgesic. It also stimulates non-propulsive rhythmic contraction of small intestine.

Pearl PM2101: Lead Poisoning/Plumbism/Saturnism

Lead Toxicity
Source of exposure

Occupational exposure

Lead paint
Route of absorption

Children - GI tract

Adults - Respiratory tract
Mechanism of action
  • Binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits
    • ALA dehydratase
    • Ferrochelatase
  • Inhibits pyrimidine 5' nucleotidase
  • Competes with calcium
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

GI tract, Bone marrow, Peripheral nerves
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Kidney

Characteristic clinical findings

(ABCDEF)

A - Anemia with basophilic stippling

B - Burtonian line (blue stippled line on gums)

C - Constipation and colic (abdominal pain)

D - Drop (wrist and foot drop) due to neuropathy

E - Encephalopathy- Mostly seen in infants presenting with severe ataxia, vomiting, lethargy, stupor, convulsions, and coma

F - Facial pallor (Earliest sign)
Diagnosis Blood lead levels
Treatment Calcium EDTA; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: 2. Which dental formula is depicted below :
questions.solution:
The given dental numbering system is known as Palmer’s notation.

Palmer’s notation is a nomenclature for the numbering and naming of teeth. Here, individual teeth within each quadrant of the dental arches are numbered from medial to distal:

* Central incisor: 1

* Lateral incisor: 2

* Canine: 3

* 1st premolar: 4

* 2nd premolar: 5

* 1st molar: 6

* 2nd molar: 7

* 3rd molar: 8

In addition, the number could be partially bracketed with a symbol that corresponds to the quadrant, as shown below:

* Right upper quadrant as  ┘

* Left upper quadrant as└

* Left lower quadrant as┌

* Right lower quadrant as  ┐



Other options:

Option A: Haderup formula: It is similar to Palmer's notation but plus sign (+) indicates upper teeth and minus sign (-) indicates lower teeth.



Option C: Universal system: Here, teeth are numbered 1 – 16 starting from upper right to upper left and 17 – 32 starting from lower left to lower right.



Option D: FDI (Federation Dentaire Internationale): It is a two-digit system.

* The first digit represents the quadrant: 1 for right upper, 2 for left upper, 3 for left lower, and 4 for right lower.

* The second digit represents the teeth of each quadrant, numbered 1 to 8, starting from the central incisor and moving away from the midline.



In modified FDI, the quadrant numbering is modified as shown below:

questions.text: 3. Minimum age for MTP is (in years)
questions.solution:
There is no prescribed minimum age for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) under the MTP Act, 1971. Therefore, among the given options, 16 years can be considered the minimum age only in a relative sense among the given options. 

As per the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP), 1971 "No pregnancy of a woman, who has not attained the age of eighteen years, or, who, having attained the age of eighteen years, is a lunatic, shall be terminated except with the consent in writing of her guardian." Therefore, medical termination of pregnancy can be performed at any age, as there is no legally defined minimum. The only distinction is that if the woman is 18 years or older, her written consent alone is required before conducting an abortion. However, if the woman is a minor (under 18 years) or is mentally ill, the written consent of her parent or legal guardian is mandatory.

Note: As per the POCSO Act, statutory rape constitutes of any consensual or nonconsensual sexual activity between a person below 18 years of age. It can be between an adult and a minor or it can also be between minors and in either case, consent remains irrelevant. Hence, abortion service providers are required to report such cases to the police. However in such cases, judicial permission is not required for abortion if there is written consent of parents or legal guardian and if the pregnancy is within legal gestational limits under the MTP Act.

questions.text: 4. A thermometer factory worker presents with lethargy, coarse tremors, and cognitive difficulties. Which of the following features would point towards chronic mercury exposure?

choices.text: Hyperkeratosis and Mees lines on  nails
Lead line on bone X Ray

questions.solution:
Features like tremors and Mad Hatter's shake points towards chronic mercury poisoning.

Chronic mercury poisoning may result from continuous accidental absorption by the workers, excessive therapeutic use, from recovery from a large dose, and if ointment is used as external application for a long time. Features of mercury poisoning include:

* Danbury tremors are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Mad Hatter's shakes/Glass blower's shakes.

* Minamata disease: This is caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury. The industrial discharges of mercury into Minamata Bay in Japan became biomethylated to form methyl mercury, which then accumulated in fish. On consumption of these fishes, people developed visual deficits and several neurological manifestations such as loss of sensation, gait, memory, cognition, etc.

* Erethism: These are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity, which is seen among persons working in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterized by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia.

* Mercurialentis: This term refers to the peculiar eye change seen due to exposure to mercury vapor. It appears as brownish deposits of mercury on the anterior lens capsule.

* Acrodynia or pink disease is thought to be an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction particularly seen in children, caused by chronic mercury exposure in any form. The onset is insidious with anorexia, insomnia, sweating, skin rash and photophobia. Hands and feet become puffy, pinkish, painful, paraesthetic with peeling of skin. 

Other options:

Option A: Hyperkeratosis and Mees lines on nails are seen in arsenic poisoning, not mercury. The image below shows transverse white lines (Leukonychia striata) called Aldrich Mees Lines typically seen in arsenic poisoning.



Option B and C: Lead line on bone X-ray and basophilic stippling are associated with lead poisoning.

Pearl PM2100: Mercury Poisoning

Features

Mercury
Source of exposure

Thermometers (elemental mercury)

Industries (inorganic mercury)

Fish (organic mercury) 
Route of absorption

Elemental - Respiratory tract (negligible through GI unless the mucosa is damaged) 

Inorganic - GI tract

Organic - GI tract
Mechanism of action

binds to sulhydryl groups of enzymes and affects

  • glutathione metabolism
Organs affected (acute toxicity)

Respiratory tract (elemental mercury)

GI tract (inorganic mercury)

Respiratory + GI tract (organic mercury)
Organs affected (chronic toxicity)

CNS, Renal (elemental mercury)

Renal (inorganic mercury)

CNS (organic mercury)
Characteristic clinical findings

 

Mnemonic: MEATS

M -

  • Mercuria lentis
  • Membranous colitis 
  • Minimata disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy

E-Erethism (personality disturbance, insomnia, and loss of memory)

A-Acrodynia (Pink disease)

T-Tremors (Coarse tremors) - Include Danbury tremors, hatter’s or Glass blower’s shakes

S-Salivation (excessive salivation)
Diagnosis Blood and/or 24 hour urine mercury level
Treatment BAL; succimer(DMSA)


Pearl PM2099: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: 5. A female is brought to the emergency with alleged history of rape by a 30year old man. She mentions that the sexual intercourse was consensual, however her mother claims that she is not yet 18 years old, whereas the patient claims she is 18years old. Which of the following skeletal survey fusions would be helpful in determining her age?

choices.text: Medial end of clavicle and Sternum
Medial end of clavicle, wrist and pelvis

questions.solution:
Skeletal survey fusions of the medial end of the clavicle, wrist and pelvis can be done in this case for determining if the age is 18 years or above. 

Bone/joint Max age of fusion Interpretation
Medial end of the clavicle 20-21 years (Appearance: 18-19 years) If appeared: ≥18 years; If fused ≥ 20 years
Wrist joint 18-19 years (Lower end of radius) If fused: ≥18 years
Pelvis

20-21 years (iliac crest, ischial tuberosity)

 If fused: ≥20 years
Elbow joint 14th year (Medial epicondyle of humerus; lateral epicondyle with
trochlea)
16th year (Lower end of humerus; olecranon to ulna; upper end of
radius)		 If fused: ≥ 16 years
Shoulder joint 17-18 years If fused: ≥17 years
Skull

45-50 years (lambdoid suture)
60-70 years (parieto-temporal suture)

 Not reliable for assessing age around 18 years
Sternum

25 years (1st and 2nd sternebrae)
40-45 years (with body)
60-70 years (manubriosternal joint)

 Not reliable for assessing age around 18 years


Other options:

Option C: If the bones of the elbow joint and shoulder joint are fused, then the age can only be determined to be ≥17 years, which does not help in disproving the patient’s claim of being 18 years.

questions.text: 6. All the following follow BNS (Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita) section 116 for grievous hurt, except:
questions.solution:
Among the options provided, severe body pain for 5 days is not an included under grievous hurt, but any hurt that causes the sufferer to be in severe body pain for 15 days is considered to be grievous hurt.

Grievous hurt (Section 116, BNS) is inflicted voluntarily on another person and comprises any of the eight kinds (clauses) enumerated below:

Clause 1 — Emasculation. (Option B) Clause 2 — Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.  Clause 3 — Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear. Clause 4 — Privation of any member or joint. Clause 5 — Destruction or permanent impairment of powers of any member or joint.  Clause 6 — Permanent disfigurement of head or face. Clause 7 — Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth. (Option A and C) Clause 8 — Any hurt that endangers life or causes the sufferer to be in severe bodily pain or unable to follow his or her ordinary pursuits for 15 days.

Related BNS sections:

Section 114 of BNS: Whoever causes bodily pain, disease or infirmity to any person is said to cause hurt. Section 115 of BNS: Whoever does any act with the intention of thereby causing hurt to any person is said “voluntarily to cause hurt” and shall be punished with imprisonment which may extend to one year, or with fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees, or with both. Section 116 of BNS:  Describes the eight clauses of grievous hurt (mentioned above). Section 117 of BNS: Whoever voluntarily causes hurt and if the hurt which he causes is grievous hurt, is said “voluntarily to cause grievous hurt” and shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine.

questions.text: 7. The triad of abrasion, bruises, and puncture laceration wounds would be seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
The triad of abrasion, bruises, and puncture laceration wounds is known as the Marshall's triad and it is is seen in bomb-blast injury. 

Marshall described the characteristic secondary blast injuries associated with bomb explosions. It includes:

* Abrasions

* Bruises/ contusions

* Puncture lacerations

Blast injuries are classified as:

* Primary injuries- effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures. External injuries are absent and are characterized by internal injuries. The middle ear, lungs, and gastrointestinal tract are the most susceptible to this.

* Secondary injuries- injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.

* Tertiary injuries- are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.

* Quaternary injuries- all other injuries caused by explosions are not included in the above three categories. eg, flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, gas, etc.

Pearl PM0979: Types of Blast Injuries

Blast injury type

Mechanism of injury

Health impact

Primary

Rapid crushing over pressure

Tympanic membrane (most common), Lung (2nd most common), eyes, GIT

Secondary

Flying debris

MARSHAL’s triad (triad of abrasions, contuisions, lacerations)

Tertiary

Blast wind

Victim is thrown in air and strikes other objects leading to fracture and blunt trauma

Quaternary

Any complicating factor not in the other three categories

Burns, histotoxic anoxia, and crush injuries


* The specific pulmonary injury of air blast is known as blast lung.

* When the explosion is in the water the pressure changes are called underwater blast. Intestinal damage is very common in underwater blast injuries.

* Solid blast refers to the wave of energy that spreads through the rigid structure when an explosive is detonated near it and people in contact with its structure can be injured.

* Caecum is most sensitive to intestinal blast injury.

questions.text: 8. A 34-year-old female comes to the emergency department with an alleged history of an accidental burn while cooking. On examination, there is dermal, dermo-epidermal involvement of the skin over the face, singeing of eyebrows is present, her front of chest, and both the upper limbs are involved. What is the total burn percentage?
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 27%-30% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

Calculation:

* Burns on front of face would account for 3.5% of burns.

* Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%  

* Burns on the front of the chest would account for 9%

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 3.5+9+18 = 30.5%

Note: The entire head accounts for 9% of total body surface area, with the face comprising roughly 7% and the neck 2%. Hence, the front of the face represents 3.5% and the front of the neck 1%.

Pearl PM0467: Wallace's rule of 9

%TBSA

Body part

%TBSA

9%

9%

9%

9%

9%

L-thigh

9%

Anterior chest

9%

R- leg

9%

Upper back

9%

L- leg

9%

Anterior abdomen

9%

Genitals

1%

Total

54%

Pearl PM0487: Degrees of Burns

  First-degree Second-degree (superficial partial thickness) Second-degree (deep partial thickness)

Third-degree (full thickness)

 Fourth-degree (full thickness)
Depth Epidermis Epidermis + superficial dermis Epidermis + most of the dermis (most skin appendages destroyed) Entire dermis + subcutaneous tissue Involves connective tissue, muscle, possibly bone
Colour/texture Red Red, edematous, and blistered Pale, mottled Hard, leathery Pale, dry, charred
Blanchable (capillary refill)  Yes Yes No No No
Pain Painful Painful Painful (only on pinprick) No No
Healing 5-10 days; no scar 10-14 days; no or minimal scar  4-8 weeks, often with scarring and contractures Prolonged, with scarring and contractures, requires skin grafting Requires skin grafting or even amputation.

questions.text: 9. Upon gastric lavage of a poison, the lavage turned out black with AgNO3. Which of the following agents can cause this?
questions.solution:
In aluminium phosphide poisoning, upon gastric lavage the lavage turns out black with AgNO3. 

Aluminium phosphide (ALP) is used as a pesticide, insecticide, and rodenticide with a garlicky odour. Silver nitrate paper test is used to detect aluminium phosphide poisoning. 

* When ALP comes in contact with moisture, it releases an active component called phosphine.

* When the silver nitrate-impregnated filter paper, comes in contact with phosphine the paper turns black in colour.

* The test is done in two methods: a. Gastric aspirate: 5 mL of gastric aspirate and 15 mL of water are put in a flask and the mouth of the flask is covered with silver nitrate-impregnated filter paper. The flask is heated at 50°C for 15 to 20 minutes. If the filter paper turns black, it indicates the presence of phosphine. b. Breath: The patient is asked to breathe in and out through a face mask which is impregnated with silver nitrate. If the face mask turns black, it indicates the presence of phosphine. The breath test is positive only if the patient ingests more than 6 grams of aluminium phosphide.

Phosphine is a toxic agent which acts by inhibiting the electron transport resulting from preferential inhibition of cytochrome oxidase. It is a systemic poison and affects all organs of the body. The presence of HCl in the stomach accelerates this reaction. Aluminium phosphite and Aluminium hypophosphite are non-toxic agents. 

Signs and symptoms include irritation of mucous membranes and acute respiratory distress in mild toxicity. Moderate toxicity produces ataxia, numbness, tremors, muscular incoordination and paralysis. Severe toxicity produces ARDS, cardiac arrhythmias, congestive heart failure, pulmonary oedema, convulsions and coma. Cardiogenic shock is the most common cause of death and is associated with higher mortality(35%- 100%). 

There is no specific antidote. Gastric lavage should not be done with warm water as on coming in contact with water, aluminium phosphide releases phosphine and increases the concentration of toxic agent phosphine. So it is done with potassium permanganate and activated charcoal. Magnesium sulphate is used to correct hypomagnesemia, arrhythmias and reduces organ toxicity. Supportive measures to treat acidosis, shock and hemodialysis can be done.

questions.text:
10. Which of the following is true regarding snake bite?

1. Elapidae is myotoxic  2. Viperidae is vasculotoxic 3. Hyaluronidase is secreted by all snake toxins 4. Toxins travel through lymphatics and superficial veins
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, 4 are true regarding snake bites.

Venomous snakes may be commonly divided into: 

* Viperidae (Russell's viper, Saw scaled viper): Venom is mainly vasculotoxic and hemolytic and causes intravascular haemolysis and depression of the coagulation mechanism. It can produce changes in the nervous system as well, but vasculotoxic effects exceed the neurotoxic effects. (Statement 2)

* Elapidae (Cobras, kraits): Venom is mainly neurotoxic, and has a primary toxicity for the respiratory and cardiac centres. Neurotoxic features are due to selective d-tubocurarin-like neuromuscular blockade which results in flaccid paralysis of muscles. It can also produce marked cardiac or vascular changes, or have a direct effect on the blood, but neurotoxic effects exceed vasculotoxic effects. (Statement 1)

* Hydrophidae (Sea snakes): Venom is myotoxic.

Snake venom is a mixture of toxalbumins and enzymes in varying proportions. The enzymatic components cause local and systemic effects and the non-enzymatic compounds provide lethality. Hyaluronidase is present in all venoms and helps in rapid spreading of the venom. Enzymes include phospholipidase A, proteases, and hyaluronidase can cause increase in cell wall permeability, with haemolysis, disruption of connective tissue, muscle and subcutaneous tissue damage leading to necrosis, and promotion of i.v. clotting and fibrinolysis resulting in a defibrinated syndrome. (Statement 3)

Snake venoms travel through lymphatics and superficial veins, and this is why pressure immobilisation is recommended as a first aid for snake bites. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. (Statement 4) However, it is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis. This application of a broad firm bandage on the bitten area is known as the Sutherland wrap.

Pearl PM2107: Mechanism of action of snake venom

Snake Toxicity Main features

Viperidae

  • Pit viper
  • Saw-scaled viper
 Vasculotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Severe
    • Edema and necrosis
  • Anticoagulant effect: widespread bleeding

Elapidae

  • Cobra
  • Krait
 Neurotoxic
  • Local reaction:
    • Mild
  • Neurotoxicity leads to muscle paralysis

Hydrophidae (sea snakes) are now considered a subfamily of Elapidae

 Myotoxic Generalized rhabdomyolysis


Saw scaled viper:



Green pit viper:



Common krait:



King cobra:



Sea snake:
